Dear Jim
Thank you for your helpful suggestions - sadly I do not have the 
=
kanji for nihiki.  The most appropriate translation for 'nihiki 
design' wo=
uld perhaps be 'two thingys design'!
Regards, John L.

> John,
> If I am p=
icturing it correctly, the rectangular openings are 
usually interpreted as=
 representing measuring boxes (masu).  The 
design with two boxes is called=

>

as the "counting word" used for two sm=
all animals. I asked my shodo 
teacher (first native speaker I remembered t=
o ask) if she could 
think of any other meaning for nihiki or a way that it=

to that motif, but no luck.

> Do you know what the kanj=
i are for that nihiki?

search on nihiki.  
Most hits are photos of pairs of dogs, cats, rabbits, e=
tc., but 
interestingly this jpg http://www005.upp.so-
net.ne.jp/minbun/new=
s/news21/nihiki.jpg
> of a kimono turned up.  Kimono sleeves are normally c=
alled sode as 
far as I know, but the two rectangular sleeves would fit the=

rectangle motif.  The nihiki  =E4=BA=8C=E5=BC=95 in the caption I thi=
nk refers 
to the kind of garment, but I don't know the meaning.  It's prob=
ably 
a red herring.  The source page is here:
>

t.ne.jp/minbun/news/news21/news21.html

d this

ve seen plenty of bamboo splitting knives with blades

ith a habaki or koshirae.  Something for a
